statements: Let $A > 0$ be a real. Then for all $d$ large enough, whp over $G \sim G(n,d/n)$, each radius-$\frac{A}{d}\log n$ ball in $G$ is 1-treelike.
For any $d > 1$, there exists $k > 0$ such that whp over $G \sim G(n,d/n)$, any connected subset of size $\le \log n$ is $k$-treelike.
For any $d > 1$, and an integer $R > 0$, whp over $G \sim G(n,d/n)$, any connected vertex subset of $G$ with at most $R$ vertices is 1-treelike (i.e we can remove at most one edge to make it a tree).

Let $\xi < \varepsilon \in (0,1)$. Then there exists a real $A(\varepsilon, \xi) > 0$ such that for all $d$ large enough, whp over $G \sim G(n,d/n)$ it holds that all connected sets of size $A \frac{\log n}{d}$ and at most $\xi n$ have average degree at least $(1 - \varepsilon)d$.

Let $\xi, \varepsilon \in (0,1)$ be arbitrary constants. Then, for all $d > \frac{32 \log 2}{\xi^2}$, whp over $G \sim G(n,d/n)$, all vertex sets $S \subseteq V_G$ of size at least $\xi n$ and at most $(1-\xi)n$ have average degree at least $(1-\varepsilon)d$, and in particular have $|E_G(S, \bar{S})| \ge \frac{d}{n}(1-\varepsilon)|S|(n-|S|)$.

For $\xi, \varepsilon \in (0,1)$ with $\xi < \varepsilon/2$, and all $d > (\frac{8 \log 2}{\varepsilon-2\xi})^2$, whp over $G \sim G(n,d/n)$, all vertex sets $S \subseteq V(G)$ of size $\ge (1 - \xi)n$ have $\mathrm{degg}(S) \ge (1 - \varepsilon)d|S|$.

For any $\xi \in (0,1]$, there exists a real $A(\xi) > 0$ such that for all $d$ large enough, whp over $G \sim G(n,d/n)$, any connected vertex set $S \subset V_G$ with $\frac{A \log n}{d} \le |S| \le \xi n$ satisfies $e_G(S) < (2\xi d/3+1)|S|$.

There exists a constant $A > 0$, such that for all $d$ large enough, whp over $G \sim G(n,d/n)$ the following holds. Let $S \subseteq V_c$ be a connected vertex set in $C$ with $|S| > A\log(n)/d$ and $\mathrm{deg}_G(S) \le \frac{1}{6} \mathrm{deg}_G(V_c)$. Then $e_G(S) \ge \frac{3}{5} \mathrm{deg}_G(S)$. The same holds if $S \subseteq V_c$ is a connected set in $C$ with $A\log(n)/d \le |S| \le n/6$.
For all $d \geq 3$, $\mu < e^{-d/2}$.
For $d \ge 4$, whp over $K \sim K(n,d)$, $n_K \ge n(1 - e^{-d/3})$. Thus also whp over $G \sim G(n,d/n)$, $n_K \ge n(1 - e^{-d/3})$.

For all d large enough, whp over G \sim G(n,d/n), |E_c| \le (1 + e^{-d/3})|E_K|.

$$ \mathrm{degg}(S_G) \ge \mathrm{deg}_k(S_K) \ge (1 - d^{-1/3})d|S_G| - 2dne^{-d^{1/3}} $$

For all $d$ large enough, whp over $G \sim G(n,d/n)$, the kernel $G_K$ is a $\frac{1}{144}$-total-degree-expander, i.e. for every set $S \subseteq V_K$ with $\mathrm{deg}_K(S) \le \frac{1}{2} \mathrm{deg}_K(G_K)$, $|E_K(S,\bar{S})| \ge \frac{1}{144} \mathrm{deg}_K(S)$.

Let $H = (V_H, E_H)$ be a $\alpha$-total degree expander, i.e. for any vertex set $S \subset V_H$ with $\mathrm{deg}_H(S) \le \frac{1}{2} \mathrm{deg}_H(H)$, $|E_H(S, \bar{S})| \ge \alpha \mathrm{deg}_H(S)$. Then, for any $\theta \in (0, \alpha)$ and any subset of edges $E' \subseteq E_H$ with $|E'| < \theta|E_H|$, it holds that $(V_H, E_H \setminus E')$ contains a component with total degree at least $(1 - \frac{2\theta}{\alpha}) \mathrm{deg}_H(V_H)$.

For all $d$ large enough, whp over $G \sim G(n,d/n)$ the following holds. Suppose that $\theta \in (0, 1/144)$ is a real and $E' \subseteq E_c$ is an edge subset such that $|E'| \le \frac{|E_c|}{144} (2\theta - \frac{1}{100})$. Then $(V_c, E_c \setminus E')$ has a component with total degree $\ge \mathrm{degg}(V_c)(1 - \theta)$, and all other components of $(V_c, E_c \setminus E')$ have total degree at most $\theta \mathrm{degg}(V_c)$.

There is an algorithm that, on input an n-vertex 1-treelike graph T rooted at v, an edge e incident to v and an integer r > 1, computes in time $2^{4r}n^{O(1)}$ rational functions $g^{+}(q, x), g^{-}(q, x)$ so that $\pi_{B_{r}^{+}(v);q,\beta}(1_e) = g^{+}(q, e^{\beta} - 1)$ and $\pi_{B_{r}^{-}(v);q,\beta}(1_e) = g^{-}(q, e^{\beta} - 1)$ for all $q, \beta > 0$.

There is an algorithm that, on input positive rationals $a,b,\varepsilon$ each with size $< n$, and integer polynomials $P(x), Q(x)$ with non-negative coefficients and size $\le n$, computes in time $\text{poly}(n)$ a number $\hat{I}$ so that $\hat{I} = I \pm \varepsilon$ where $I = \int_a^b \frac{P(x)}{Q(x)} dx$.
proofs:
Proof. Here, $k > 0$ will be a sufficiently large constant we specify later.
Fix $1 < s < \log n$. We union bound over connected trees of size $s$ and events "T is a subtree of G with $e(V(T)) > s - 1 + k$". Fix any tree $T$ of size $s$. Then note that conditional on $T$ being a subgraph of $G$, we have that $e(V(T)) \sim s - 1 + \text{Bin}(\binom{s}{2} - (s - 1), d/n) \le s + \text{Bin}(s^2, d/n)$.
We have $\text{P}(\text{Bin}(s^2,d/n) \ge k) \le s^{2k}(d/n)^k$ by union bound. Lemma 31 gives that the expected number of connected trees of size $s$ is at most $n(ed)^s$, thus expected number of subtrees $T$ of $G$ of size $s$ and $> s - 1 + k$ edges between vertices of $T$ is at most
$$ \left(\frac{ds^2}{n}\right)^k n(ed)^s = n \exp\{s \log(ed) + k \log(ds^2/n)\} < d^k n \exp\{\log(ed) \log n - k \log(n/\log n)\} $$
For $k > \log(ed) + 2$ and all $n$ large enough, this is $< d^k/n$. Then union bound over $\log n$ possible sizes and then using Markov inequality gives probability $\le \log n/\sqrt{n} = o(1)$.

Proof. Assume we have some $A > 0$ for now. Since for any connected set of $G$, there is a subtree of $G$ with this vertex set, it is enough to show that
$$ \sum_{\substack{\text{T a possible subtree of G} \\ |V_G(T)| \ge A \log n/d}} \mathbb{E}[\mathbb{1}\{T \text{ is a subtree of } G \text{ and } \text{deg}_G(T) \ge (1-\varepsilon)d|V_G(T)|\}] = o(1), $$
and then we the lemma follows from Markov inequality.
Fix any possible tree $T$ with $|V_G(T)| = s$. Then the expectation in the sum for this tree can be rewritten as
$$ \mathbb{E}[\mathbb{1}\{T \text{ a subtree of } G\}] \mathbb{P}(\text{deg}_G(T) < (1-\varepsilon)ds \mid T \text{ a subtree of } G). $$
Note that conditional on “$T$ a subtree of $G$”, $\text{deg}_G(T) = 2e_G(T) + |E_G(V_G(T), \overline{V_G(T)})| \ge |E_G(V_G(T), \overline{V_G(T)})| \sim \text{Bin}(s(n-s), d/n)$. Using $n-s > n(1-\xi)$, this is dominated by $\text{Bin}(sn(1-\xi), d/n)$. Thus $\mathbb{P}(\text{deg}_G(T) < (1-\varepsilon)ds \mid T \text{ a subtree of } G)$ is at most
$$ \mathbb{P}(\text{Bin}(s(1-\xi)n, d/n) \le (1-\varepsilon)ds), $$
by Chernoff this is at most $\exp\{-\frac{ds(\varepsilon-\xi)^2}{2(1-\xi)}\}$.
Then when we sum first through all sizes $s \ge \frac{A \log n}{d}$ and using Lemma 31 to bound the expected number of a subtrees of given size, we obtain that the extended number of subtrees of $G$ of size $\frac{A \log n}{d} \le s \le \xi n$ with average degree $< (1-\varepsilon)ds$ is at most
$$ \sum_{s=\frac{A \log n}{d}}^{\xi n} \mathbb{E}[\#\text{subtrees of G with s vertices}] \exp\left\{-\frac{ds(\varepsilon-\xi)^2}{2(1-\xi)}\right\} \le \sum_{s=\frac{A \log n}{d}}^{\xi n} n(ed)^s \exp\left\{-\frac{ds(\varepsilon-\xi)^2}{2(1-\xi)}\right\}. $$
For all $d$ sufficiently large, $\frac{d(\varepsilon-\xi)^2}{2(1-\xi)} - 1 - \log d > \frac{d(\varepsilon-\xi)^2}{3(1-\xi)}$, and hence the sum is
$$ O\left(\exp\left\{\log n \left[1 - \frac{A(\varepsilon-\xi)^2}{3(1-\xi)}\right]\right\}\right). $$
For any $A > \frac{3(1-\xi)}{(\varepsilon-\xi)^2}$, this is $o(1)$, hence the lemma follows.

Proof. For any given set $S$ with size $\xi n \le |S| \le (1-\xi)n$, $\text{degg}(S)$ is a sum of independent $2\text{Bin}(\binom{|S|}{2}, d/n)$ and $\text{Bin}(|S|(n-|S|), d/n)$ random variables, corresponding to inner edges, and edges going outside of $S$ respectively.
First we bound $P(2\text{Bin}(\binom{|S|}{2}, d/n) < (1-\varepsilon)d|S|^2/n)$. By Chernoff, for n large enough so that $(1-\varepsilon)/(|S|-1) < \varepsilon/2$ and $1/n < \xi/2$, this is at most $\exp\{-\frac{d\varepsilon^2\xi^2}{32}\}$.
Then for the proportion of the degree corresponding to the edges of going from $S$ to $\bar{S}$, this is $\sim \text{Bin}(|S|(n-|S|), d/n)$, and by Chernoff $P(\text{Bin}(|S|(n-|S|), d/n) < (1-\varepsilon)\frac{d|S|(n-|S|)}{n}) \le \exp\{-d\varepsilon^2\xi^2 n/2\}$.
Hence by union bound, there is such a set with average degree $< (1-\varepsilon)d$ with probability at most $\exp\{-d\varepsilon^2\xi^2n/2\}+\exp\{-d\varepsilon^2\xi(n-1)\}$. There are at most $2^n$ such sets $S$, thus by another union bound and by the condition on $d$, we obtain that the probability of a large set of small average degree existing is at most $\exp\{-\Omega(n)\} = o(1)$.

Proof. For any vertex set $S$, $\mathrm{degg}(S) \ge 2e_G(S) \sim 2\mathrm{Bin}(\binom{|S|}{2}, d/n)$. If $|S| \ge (1 - \xi)n$, then $\mathrm{E}[\mathrm{Bin}(\binom{|S|}{2}, d/n)] \ge \frac{d|S|(|S|-1)}{2n} \ge d|S|(1 - \xi - 1/n)/2$. For $n \ge 1/\xi$, this is $\ge d|S|(1 - 2\xi)/2 > (1 - \varepsilon)d|S|/2$. Use Chernoff bound to get that (the last inequality uses that $\frac{1-\varepsilon}{1-2\xi} \ge 1$),
$$ P(e_G(S) \le (1 - \varepsilon)d|S|/2) \le \exp\{-\frac{d|S|(\varepsilon - 2\xi)^2}{8(1 - 2\xi)}\} \le \exp\{-dn(\varepsilon - 2\xi)^2/8\}. $$
Thus, union bounding over at most $2^n$ possible sets, the probability that exists a vertex set $S$ with $|S| \ge (1 - \xi)n$ and $\mathrm{degg}(S) \le (1 - \varepsilon)d|S|$ is at most $\exp\{n[\log 2 - d(\varepsilon - 2\xi)^2/8]\}$, and by the lower bound on $d$, this is $\exp\{-\Omega(n)\} = o(1)$.

Proof. Assume we have some $A > 0$ for now. We use Markov inequality on the expected number of subtrees of $G$, $T$ with $\frac{A \log n}{d} < |V_G(T)| \le \xi n$ (as every connected set has a spanning tree). Thus it is enough to show
$$ \sum_{\substack{T \text{ a tree} \\ \frac{A \log n}{d} < |V_G(T)| \le \xi n}} P(e_G(V_G(T)) \ge (\xi d + 1)|V_G(T)| | T \text{ a subtree of } G)P(T \text{ a subtree of } G) = o(1) $$
Fix a tree $T$ with $s$ vertices. Then conditional on $T$ being a subgraph of $G$, $e_G(V(T)) \sim s-1 + \text{Bin}(\binom{s}{2} - (s-1), d/n)$. Since $\binom{s}{2} - s - 1 < s^2/2$, we can bound
$$ P(e_G(V_G(T)) \ge (2\xi d/3 + 1)s | T \text{ a subtree of } G) \le P(\text{Bin}(s^2/2, d/n) \ge 2\xi ds/3). $$
Noting that $s < \xi n$, Chernoff bound gives that this is at most $\exp\{-\xi ds/216\}$.
By Lemma 31, the expected number of subtrees of size $s$ is at most $n(ed)^s$. Hence summing over possible subtree sizes, we get that the expected number of "bad" subtrees is at most
$$ \sum_{\frac{A \log n}{d} < s \le \xi n} n[de^{1+\xi d/216}]^s. $$
For all $d$ large enough, $de^{1+\xi d/216} < \exp\{-\xi d/250\}$, and thus then the sum is $O(n^{1-A\xi/250})$, which is $o(1)$ for any $A > \frac{250}{\xi}$.

Proof. By Proposition 10 and Lemma 35, there exists a real $A > 0$ such that for all $d$ large enough, whp, any connected set $|S|$ with size at least $\frac{A \log n}{d}$ has $\mathrm{deg}_G(S) > \frac{9d|S|}{10}$, and if furthermore $|S| \le \frac{n}{6}$, then $e_G(S) \le (1+\frac{1}{5})|S|$.
Since $\mathrm{deg}_G(S) = 2e_G(S) + |E_G(S, \bar{S})|$, we can rearrange and then use the above inequalities to obtain that for any connected vertex set $S$ with $\frac{A \log n}{d} \le |S| \le \frac{n}{6}$,
$$ \frac{|E_G(S, \bar{S})|}{\mathrm{deg}_G(S)} = 1 - \frac{2e_G(S)}{\mathrm{deg}_G(S)} \ge 1 - \frac{20}{9d} - \frac{1}{5}. $$
For all $d$ large enough, this is at most $\frac{3}{5}$. To finish the proof, note that whenever $|S| \ge \frac{n}{6}$, its total degree is at least $\frac{3dn}{10}$. But whp $\frac{3nd}{10} > |E_G| \ge |E_c|$, giving $\frac{\mathrm{deg}_G(V_c)}{10} < \frac{3nd}{10} \le \mathrm{deg}_G(S)$. Thus whenever $S$ has $\mathrm{deg}_G(S) \le \mathrm{deg}_G(V_c)/10$, then also $|S| \le n/6$, thus the exansion applies.

Proof. The function $x \to xe^{-x}$ is (strictly) decreasing on $x \in (1, \infty)$ and (strictly) increasing on $x \in (0, 1)$, thus there is a unique conjugate for each $d > 1$ in $(0, 1)$ and in particular, note that if for $a \in (0, 1)$ it holds that $ae^{-a} > de^{-d}$, then $\mu(d) < a$. We can easily verify that $e^{-d/2}e^{-e^{-d/2}} > de^{-d}$ holds for all $d \geq 3$.

Proof. In the model from Proposition 36, we have $\Delta \sim N(d-\mu, 1/n)$, hence whp $\Delta > d-e^{-d/2}$ (we used the inequality $\mu < e^{-d/2}$. from the previous lemma). Then note $n-n_K = \sum_i 1\{D_i < 3\}$. Note that while $D_i$'s are conditional to have an even sum, this event has a probability bounded below by a constant, thus it is enough to show that whp sum of n i.i.d. Bernoulli(P(Poisson($\Delta$) < 3)) r.v.s. is at most $ne^{-d/3}$. Whp (when on $\Delta > d-e^{-d/2}$) they have mean $\le ne^{-d-e^{-d/2}} (1+d-e^{-d/2} + (d-e^{-d/2})^2/2)$. We can verify that for all $d \ge 4$, there exists constant (independent of n) $\delta(d) > 0$ such that this mean is $\le ne^{-d/3} - n\delta$. By standard Chernoff bounds this implies whp $n - n_K \le ne^{-d/3}$, so the result follows. From contiguity of $K(n, d)$ (Proposition 36), and since $n_K \le n_C$, the rest of the lemma follows.

Proof. We have $\Delta \sim N(d - \mu, 1/n)$, thus whp $d - \mu - \frac{1}{2}e^{-d/3} < \Delta$. For $d \geq 3$, $\mu \leq e^{-d/2} < e^{-d/3}$, hence $\Delta > d - \frac{3}{2}e^{-d/3}$.
From the previous lemma, whp $n-n_K \leq ne^{-d/3}$. Also, we can write $2|E_K| \geq \sum^n D_i - 2(n-n_K)$. It is therefore enough to show that whp $\sum^n D_i \geq n(d-2e^{-d/3})$. Since the probability of $\sum D_i$ being even is bounded below by a constant, it is enough to show that whp $\text{Poisson}(\Delta n) \geq n(d - 2e^{-d/3})$. Since $\Delta \geq d - \frac{3}{2}e^{-d/3}$ whp, we have from (9) that $P(\text{Poisson}(\Delta n) \leq n(d - 2e^{-d/3})) = e^{-\Omega(n)})$. The result for $G(n, d/n)$ follows from contiguity of $K(n, d)$.

Proof. We have that whp $|E_C| < \frac{dn}{2} + ne^{-d/3}$ (since $|E_C| \le |E_G| = \frac{nd}{2} + o(n)$) and $|E_K| \ge \frac{dn}{2} - 2ne^{-d/3}$ (by previous lemma). Thus
$$ \frac{|E_C|}{|E_K|} \le \frac{d/2+e^{-d/3}}{d/2-2e^{-d/3}} = 1 + \frac{3e^{-d/3}}{d/2-2e^{-d/3}}. $$
For all d large enough, $\frac{3}{d/2-2e^{-d/3}} \le 1$, hence giving that $|E_C|$ is at most $(1+e^{-d/3})|E_K|$.

Proof. We first claim that whp, the number of vertices of degree $< (1 – d^{-1/3})d$ in the kernel is at most $o(n) + ne^{-d^{1/3}}$. Note it is enough, by Proposition 36, to show this for $K \sim K(n, d)$.
There, $\Delta \sim N(d – \mu, 1/n)$, and hence whp $\Delta > d - e^{-d/3}$ (recall that by Lemma 37, $\mu \le e^{-d/2}$ for all $d \ge 3$). The number of kernel vertices with degree $< (1 – d^{-1/3})d$ is at most $\sum_i 1\{D_i \le (1-d^{-1/3})d\}$. Since we are proving a whp result, we can drop the conditioning on the sum of $D_i$'s being even, so it is enough to bound the sum of i.i.d. $1\{\text{Poisson}(d−2\mu) < (1−d^{−1/3})d\}$ r.v.s. Since $d - e^{-d/3} > (1 − d^{-1/3})d$, we use (9) to get
$$ P(\text{Poisson}(d-e^{-d/3}) \le (1-d^{-1/3})d) \le \exp\left(-\frac{(d^{2/3}-e^{-d/3})^2}{d+d^{2/3}-2e^{-d/3}}\right) \le e^{-d^{1/3}} $$
for all d large enough. Then using a Chernoff bound for the sum of Bernoulli r.v.s., whp $\sum_i 1\{D_i < (1-d^{-1/3})d\} \le o(n) + ne^{-\frac{1}{2}d^{1/3}}$, which finishes the claim.
Now, all vertices in $G$ that correspond to kernel vertices with degree $> (1 – d^{-1/3})d$ also have degree $\ge (1-d^{-1/3})d$. It remains to account for the remaining vertices. The number of these vertices is $n - n_K \le ne^{-d/3}$, where the last inequality follows whp from Lemma 38. Thus the number of vertices with degree $\le (1 – d^{-1/3})d$ in $G$ (and thus in $C$) is whp at most $n(e^{-d/3}+o(1)+e^{-d^{1/3}})$, which is at most $2e^{-d^{1/3}}$ for all d large enough.
For the second part of the proposition it is enough to note that $|S_K| \ge |S_G| – (n – n_K) \ge |S_G| - ne^{-d/3}$, and all but $ne^{-\frac{1}{2}d^{-1/3}} + o(n)$ of these vertices have degree $> (1 – d^{-1/3})d$, and the remaining vertices have degree $< d$.
Recall that kernel is formed from $C$ by considering the maximal degree-2 subgraph of $C$ and then contracting the edges, and then my contracting the subtrees. The degree “lost” by removing attached trees is exactly twice the number of tree vertices (as for any tree with N vertices, its total degree is exactly $2(N − 1)$). Also clearly, the degree lost by contracting edges is twice the number vertices lost this way. Thus in total, the degree lost when going from $C$ to the kernel is at most $2e^{-d/3}$, thus giving that
$$ \mathrm{deg}_K(S_K) \ge (1 – d^{-1/3})d|S_G| – dn[e^{-d/3} + o(1) + e^{-d^{-1/3}}] \ge (1-d^{-1/3})d|S_G| - 2dne^{-d^{1/3}} $$
for all d large enough. To conclude, $\mathrm{degg}(S_G) \ge \mathrm{deg}_K(S_K)$ clearly holds.

Proof. Write
$$ q(e^\beta - 1)^{|E_C|} \prod_{\gamma \in \Gamma_v^{\text{ord}}(F)} w_v^{\text{ord}}(\gamma) = q^{1+\sum_{\gamma \in \Gamma_v^{\text{ord}}(F)} c'(\gamma)} (e^\beta - 1)^{|E_C|-\sum_{\gamma \in \Gamma_v^{\text{ord}}(F)} e_{\text{out}}(\gamma)} $$
Every out-edge of $F$ is in exactly one ordered polymer of $F$, thus $|E_C \setminus F| = \sum_{\gamma \in \Gamma_v^{\text{ord}}(F)} e_{\text{out}}(\gamma)$. It remains to show that $c(F) = 1 + \sum_{\gamma \in \Gamma_v^{\text{ord}}(F)} c'(\gamma)$.
By Lemma 16 whp $G$ is such that for all $F \in \Omega_C^{\text{ord}}$, $(V_C, F)$ contains a giant component with total degree $> \frac{1}{2}\text{deg}_G(G_C)$. The 1-term in the above equality corresponds to the giant. Now consider any non-giant component $\kappa$ of $(V_C, F)$. Its vertices must be in $V(v, F)$, and thus in $V_\gamma$ for some $\gamma \in \Gamma_v^{\text{ord}}(F)$, hence also $E_C(V(\kappa), V(\kappa)) \subseteq E_{\text{out}}(\gamma)$. Since $\kappa$ is connected in $(V_C, F)$, it must be connected in $(V_C, E_C \setminus E_{\text{out}}(\gamma))$, as $F \subseteq E_C \setminus E_{\text{out}}(\gamma)$, thus it is accounted for in $c'(\gamma)$. Therefore $1 + c(F) \le 1 + \sum_{\gamma \in \Gamma_v^{\text{ord}}(F)} c'(\gamma)$.
Now consider $\kappa$ to be a non-giant component of $(V_C, E_C \setminus E_{\text{out}}(\gamma))$ for some $\gamma \in \Gamma_v^{\text{ord}}(F)$. Since $(V_C, E_C)$ is connected, $E_{\text{out}}(\gamma)$ contains an out-edge $e$ incident to some vertex $w$ of $\kappa$. Since $F \subseteq E_C \setminus E_{\text{out}}(\gamma)$, the component of $w$ in $(V_C, F)$, $\kappa'$, must be a subgraph of $\kappa$. Clearly, $\kappa'$ must also be non-giant, thus all of its vertices are in $V(v, F)$. Since non-singleton polymers are maximal connected subgraphs consisting of vertices in $V(v, F)$, there is a unique polymer $\gamma'$ containing vertices in $V(\kappa') \subseteq V(\kappa)$. Since $e$ is an out-edge incident to $w$, $e \in E_{\text{out}}(\gamma')$. Thus $e$ is not in a singleton polymer in $\Gamma_v^{\text{ord}}(F)$, so $\gamma$ must be a non-singleton polymer with an endpoint of $e$ contained in $V_\gamma$. But then $V_\gamma \cup \{w\}$ is a connected subset in $(V_C, E_C)$, and thus in particular so is $V_\gamma \cup V_{\gamma'}$. Since polymers of $F$ do not intersect, it must be the case $\gamma = \gamma'$ and $\kappa = \kappa'$. Thus each non-giant component $\kappa$ of $(V_C, E_C \setminus E_{\text{out}}(\gamma))$ for any $\gamma \in \Gamma_v^{\text{ord}}(F)$ is also a non-giant component of $(V_C, E_C)$ and for any $\gamma' \in \Gamma_v^{\text{ord}}(F)$, $\gamma' \neq \gamma$, $\kappa$ is not a non-giant component of $(V_C, E_C \setminus E_{\text{out}}(\gamma'))$. This finished the second part of the equality and thus the proof.

Proof. It is sufficient to show that for any connected set of total degree $\le \frac{1}{2} \mathrm{deg}_K(G_K)$, the number of edges in the cut is at least $\frac{1}{144}$-fraction of the total degree. Then to handle arbitrary vertex set, combine the results for its connected components.
By Lemma 38, whp $n_K \ge n(1 - e^{-d/3})$, thus whp $\log^2 n_K \ge \log n$. Then whp, by contiguity of $K(n, d)$ and Lemma 42, for any $|S_K| \le \log n$, $|E_K(S_K, \bar{S_K})| \ge \mathrm{deg}_K(S_K)/144$. Also assume that $d$ is large enough so that all previously proven whp results hold, in particular: Propositions 10 (with $\varepsilon = \frac{1}{10}$), and 11, and 35 (with $\xi = 2/3$). Further on we assume $G$ is such that the properties from these results hold.
Let $S_G \subseteq V_G$ be the set as in the Observation 43. We divide the proof into four cases, based on the size of $S_K$ and $S_G$.
1. If $|S_K| \le \log n$, then the Lemma 42 gives $|E_K(S_K, \bar{S_K})| \ge \mathrm{deg}_K(S_K)/144$.
2. If $\log n \le |S_K| \le |S_G| \le \frac{n}{6}$ (note that the middle inequality always holds), then by Proposition 11 and the above observation we get
$$|E_K(S_K, \bar{S_K})| = |E_G(S_G, \bar{S_G})| \ge \frac{3}{5} \mathrm{deg}_G(S_G) \ge \frac{3}{5} \mathrm{deg}_K(S_K),$$
where the last inequality follows from $\mathrm{deg}_K(S_K) \le \mathrm{deg}_G(S_G)$.
3. If $\frac{n}{6} < |S_G| \le \frac{2n}{3}$, then Lemma 35 we gives $e_G(S_G) \le (\frac{2}{9}d + 1)|S_G|$, and Proposition 10 gives $\mathrm{deg}_G(S_G) \ge \frac{9d}{10}|S_G|$. Thus
$$ \frac{|E_K(S_K, \bar{S_K})|}{\mathrm{deg}_K(S_K)} \ge \frac{|E_G(S_G, \bar{S_G})|}{\mathrm{deg}_G(S_G)} = 1 - \frac{2e_G(S_G)}{\mathrm{deg}_G(S_G)} \ge 1 - \frac{8}{9} - \frac{10}{9d}, $$
where the first inequality follows from $\mathrm{deg}_K(S_K) \le \mathrm{deg}_G(S_G)$ and the second from the above inequalities. To finish, note that for all $d$ large enough, this is at least $\frac{1}{10}$.
4. Finally, we rule out the case $|S_G| \ge \frac{2n}{3}$.
By Proposition 41, $\mathrm{deg}_K(S_K) \ge (1 - d^{-1/3})d|S_G| - 2dne^{-d^{1/3}} \ge nd[\frac{1}{3} - d^{-1/3} - 2e^{-d^{1/3}}] \ge 2dn/3$ for all $d$ large enough. But also (whp) $|E_K| \le |E_G| \le nd/2 + o(n)$, so for any such set $S_K$, $\mathrm{deg}_K(S_K) \ge \frac{1}{2} \mathrm{deg}_K(G_K)$, hence we can rule this case out.

Proof. Let $C_1, \dots, C_k$ be components of $(V_H, E_H \setminus E')$ and wlog $C_1$ is the component of the highest total degree.
Case 1. $\mathrm{deg}_H(C_1) < \frac{\mathrm{deg}_H(V_H)}{2}$. Then for all $1 \le i \le k$, $\mathrm{deg}_H(C_i) < \frac{\mathrm{deg}_H(V_H)}{2}$, and hence by Proposition 44 to get $|E'| \ge \sum_{i=1}^k \alpha \mathrm{deg}_H(C_i) = \alpha|E_H|$. However, $|E'| \le \theta|E_H| \le \alpha|E_H|$. Contradiction, this case cannot happen.
Case 2. $\mathrm{deg}_H(C_1) \ge \frac{\mathrm{deg}_H(V_H)}{2}$. Then it follows $\mathrm{deg}_H(C_2 \cup \dots \cup C_k) \le \mathrm{deg}_H(V_H)/2$, and thus we can use the third expansion property to get
$$ |E'| \ge \alpha \mathrm{deg}_H(C_2 \cup \dots \cup C_k) = \alpha(\mathrm{deg}_H(V_H) - \mathrm{deg}_H(C_1)) $$
This gives $\mathrm{deg}_H(C_1) \ge \mathrm{deg}_H(V_H) - |E'|/\alpha \ge (1 - \frac{\theta}{\alpha}) \mathrm{deg}_H(V_H)$.

Proof of Lemma 12. Let $E'_K$ be the set of edges in the kernel whose corresponding induced path in G contains at least one edge from $E'$. Notice this does not increase the number of edges, i.e. $|E'_K| \le |E'|$. Also, from Lemma 40, $|E_c| \le (1 + e^{-d/3})|E_K|$, thus
$$
|E'_K| \le \frac{|E_K|}{144} (2\theta - 2e^{-d/3})(1 + e^{-d/3}) < \frac{|E_K|}{144}
$$
Note that for all $d$ large enough, $\frac{1}{100} \le 2e^{-d/3}$, thus $|E'| \le \frac{|E_c|}{144}(2\theta - 2e^{-d/3})$. Hence we can apply Lemma 45 to get that $(V_K, E_K \setminus E'_K)$ contains a giant component of total degree at least
$$
(1 - (\theta - e^{-d/3})(1+e^{-d/3})) \mathrm{deg}_K(V_K) \ge \frac{1 - (\theta - e^{-d/3})(1+e^{-d/3})}{1+e^{-d/3}} \mathrm{degg}(V_c) \ge (1-\theta)\mathrm{degg}(V_c).
$$
To finish, we note that vertices of this component are also in the same component of $(V_c, E_c \setminus E')$, their degrees do not decrease, and hence there is a component of $(V_c, E_c \setminus E')$ with total degree $\ge (1 - \theta)\mathrm{degg}(V_c)$. The lemma follows.

Proof. We divide the proof into two cases. First consider the case $|V_G(\gamma)| \ge \frac{n}{6}$. Then also note that since $\gamma \in \Gamma^{\mathrm{dis}}(F)$, $|e_G(\gamma)| \le |F| \le \eta|E_C| \le 3\eta dn/4$ (the last inequality follows whp over G from $|E_C| \le |E_G| = nd/2 + o(n)$).
Thus, using that $e^\beta - 1 \le q^{(2+1/10)/d}$,
$$w^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma) \le q^{1-n/6+\frac{2+1/10}{d}(3\eta dn/4)} \le q^{1-n[1/6-2\eta]}.$$
Since $\eta < 1/30$, $1/6 - 2\eta \ge 1/10$. Thus $w^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma) \le q^{1-n/10} \le q^{1-|V_G(\gamma)|/10}$, where the last inequality follows from $|V_G(\gamma)| \le n$.
Now let $A$ be the constant from Lemma 35 (with $\xi = n/6$) and thus consider the case $\frac{A \log n}{d} \le |V_G(\gamma)| \le n/6$. By the Lemma, whp it holds that any such $\gamma$ has $e_G(V_G(\gamma)) \le (d/9+1)|V_G(\gamma)|$. Since we have $e_G(\gamma) \le e_G(V_G(\gamma)) \le (d/9+1)|V_G(\gamma)|$, we combine the inequalities to obtain:
$$w^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma) \le q^{1-|V_G(\gamma)|(1-\frac{2+1/10}{d}(d/9+1))} \le q^{1-|V_G(\gamma)|(23/30-21/10d)}.$$
For all $d$ large enough this is at most $q^{1-|V_G(\gamma)|/10}$.

Proof. For the first part, expand out the rhs using polymer weight definition,
$$ q^{n_c} \prod_{\gamma \in \Gamma^{\mathrm{dis}}(F)} w^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma) = q^{n_c+|\Gamma^{\mathrm{dis}}(F)|-\sum_{\gamma \in \Gamma^{\mathrm{dis}}(F)} |V_G(\gamma)|} (e^\beta - 1)^{\sum_{\gamma \in \Gamma^{\mathrm{dis}}(F)} e_G(\gamma)} $$
Disordered polymers of $F$ are exactly the connected components on $(V_C, F)$, thus $|\Gamma^{\mathrm{dis}}(F)| = c(F)$, $\sum_{\gamma \in \Gamma^{\mathrm{dis}}(F)} |V_G(\gamma)| = n_c$. Every in-edge of $F$ is in a polymer and polymers of $F$ do not overlap, thus also $\sum_{\gamma \in \Gamma^{\mathrm{dis}}(F)} e_G(\gamma) = |F|$. Hence the the first part of the lemma follows.

Next, notice that any disordered polymer containing no edges has weight 1. So for any $\gamma = (\{v\}, \emptyset)$, the inequality in the lemma is trivial. So suppose $\gamma$ is a polymer with at least one edge. Then for any $F \in \Omega_C^{\mathrm{dis}}$ with $\gamma \in \Gamma^{\mathrm{dis}}(F)$, let $F' := F \setminus E_G(\gamma)$ and note $F' \ne F$. The components of $(V_C, F')$ are exactly the components of $(V_C, F)$, except for the vertices of $\gamma$, that are in $\gamma$ in $(V_C, F)$, but in isolated vertices in $(V_C, F')$. Thus $w_C(F') = w_C(F)q^{|V_G(\gamma)|-1}(e^\beta-1)^{-e_G(\gamma)} = w_C(F)/w^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma)$. Let $\Omega_C^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma) = \{F \in \Omega_C^{\mathrm{dis}} | \gamma \in \Gamma^{\mathrm{dis}}(F)\}$. Then we can write
$$ \pi_C^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma \in \Gamma^{\mathrm{dis}}(\cdot)) = \frac{\sum_{F \in \Omega_C^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma)} w_C(F)}{\sum_{F \in \Omega_C^{\mathrm{dis}}} w_C(F)} = \frac{\sum_{F \in \Omega_C^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma)} w_C(F)}{\sum_{F \in \Omega_C^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma)} (w_C(F) + w_C(F'))} \le \frac{1}{1+1/w^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma)} \le w^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma). $$

Proof. By Lemmas 47 and 35, there is $A > 0$ such that for all $d$ large enough, whp $G$ is such that for all $\beta \in (0, \beta_1]$, any polymer $\gamma$ with at least $\frac{A \log n}{d}$ vertices has weight at most $q^{1-|V_G(\gamma)|/10}$, and also for any connected vertex set $S \subseteq V_C$ of size at least $\frac{A \log n}{d}$ has $e_G(S) \le (2d/3+1)|S|$. Also by union bound and Markov inequality applied to Lemma 31, whp $G$ is such that for each $1 \le s \le n$ there are at most $n^{5/2}(ed)^s$ connected subsets of size $s$. Further on, assume $G$ is such that the above holds. By the previous lemma and by union bound, it is sufficient to prove that
$$ \sum_{\substack{\gamma \in \cup_{F \in \Omega_C^{\mathrm{dis}}} \Gamma^{\mathrm{dis}} \\ |V_G(\gamma)| \ge A \log n/d}} w^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma) \le q^{-A \log n/(25d)}. $$
For any connected subset $S$ of the size $\ge \frac{A \log n}{d}$, $e_G(S) \le (2d/3+1)|S|$, hence there are at most $2^{(2d/3+1)|S|}$ possible connected subgraphs of $G$ with the vertex set $S$. Hence the number of polymers with $s \ge \frac{A \log n}{d}$ vertices is at most $n^{5/2}(ed)^s 2^{(2d/3+1)s}$. By Lemma 47, for any polymer with $s \ge \frac{A \log n}{d}$ vertices, its weight is at most $q^{1-s/10}$. Thus summing through all possible sizes gives us that the the sum is at most
$$ \sum_{s \ge (A/d) \log n} n^{5/2}(ed)^s 2^{(2d/3+1)s} q^{1-s/10} = q n^{5/2} \sum_{s \ge (A/d) \log n} [2^{2d/3+1} ed q^{-1/10}]^s. $$
Finally, provided that $q$ is sufficiently large, $2^{2d/3+1}edq^{-1/10} < q^{-1/20}$, and for $q$ large enough, the sum can be also bound by $O(n^{5/2}q^{-A \log n/(20d)}) \le q^{-A \log n/(25d)}$.

Proof. By Lemmas 33, and 34, whp all vertex sets in $G$ with size at least $\ge \eta n$ have average degree is at least $3d/4$. Also by the second part of the first Lemma, whp, for any vertex set $S \subseteq V_G$ with size between $\eta n$ and $(1-\eta)n$, $|E_G(S, \bar{S})| \ge \frac{5d}{6}|S|(n-|S|)$. Also whp $n_C \ge (1-e^{-d/3})n$. Assume further on $G$ satisfies these properties.

Also by the choice of $\eta$ and by Lemma 12, whp $G$ is such that for any $F \in \Omega_C^{\mathrm{ord}}$, there is a giant component in $(V_C, F)$ with total degree $\ge \frac{9}{10} \mathrm{deg}_G(V_C)$. Thus the set $S$ of vertices in the non-giant components has total degree $\le \frac{1}{10} \mathrm{deg}_G(V_C)$. Note that all edges in $E_G(S, \bar{S})$ are in $E_C \setminus F$. We consider three cases, based on the size of $S$.

If $|S| \ge \frac{\eta n}{3}$, then $\mathrm{deg}_G(S) \ge \frac{3d}{4}\frac{\eta n}{3}$. But also $\mathrm{deg}_G(S) \le \frac{\mathrm{deg}_G(V_C)}{10} \le \frac{dn}{10}+o(n)$, which is a contradiction.

Next consider the case $\eta n \le |S| \le \frac{n}{3}$. Then $|E_C \setminus F| \ge |E_G(S, \bar{S})| \ge \frac{5\eta nd}{9}$. But whp $|E_C| \le \frac{dn}{2}+o(n) < \frac{3}{4}dn$, so this contradicts $|E_C \setminus F| \le \eta|E_C|$.

Thus the only remaining possibility is $|S| \le \eta n$. Then $c(F) \le |S| \le \eta n + 1$ and $|F| \le |E_C| \le nd/2 + \eta n$ (the last inequality holds whp). Thus we obtain that $w_C(F) \le q^{\eta n+1}(e^\beta-1)^{nd/2+\eta n} < q^{\eta n+2-1/10 \cdot nd + \eta n} = q^{n[1-1/20+2\eta]}$.

Since $\emptyset$ is a configuration with a weight $q^{n_C} > q^{n(1-e^{-d/3})}$, it follows that $Z_C > q^{n-ne^{-d/3}}$. There are at most $2^{|E_C|} = 2^{nd/2+\eta n}$ ordered configurations, therefore,
$$ \frac{Z_C^{\mathrm{dis}}}{Z_C} \le 2^{nd/2+\eta n} q^{n[-1+1-1/10+2\eta+e^{-d/3}]} = \exp\{n[d\ln 2/2 + \log q(-1/10 + 2\eta + e^{-d/3})]\}. $$
Since $1/10 - 2\eta - e^{-d/3} > 1/20$ for all $d$ large enough, this becomes $\exp\{nd \ln 2/2 - n \log q/20\}$, which is $\le e^{-n}$ for all $q$ large enough.

Proof. Let $F \in \Omega_C^{\mathrm{dis}}$. Then $|F| \leq \eta|E_C|$, and thus $w_C(F) \leq q^{n_c} (e^\beta - 1)^{\eta|E_C|}$. $|\Omega_C^{\mathrm{dis}}| \leq 2^{|E_C|}$, and since $F = E_C$ is a configuration, $Z_C \geq q(e^\beta-1)^{|E_C|}$. Whp $|E_C| \leq \frac{dn}{2} + \eta n$, hence $|\Omega_C^{\mathrm{dis}}| \leq 2^{n(d/2+\eta)}$. Combining the inequalities and using that $\beta \geq \beta_1$,
$$ \frac{Z_C^{\mathrm{dis}}}{Z_C} \leq 2^{(d/2+\eta)n} q^{n_c} (e^\beta - 1)^{-(1-\eta)|E_C|} \leq q^{n-(1-\eta)(2+1/10)|E_C|}. $$
Lemma 39 gives us that whp $|E_C| \geq \frac{dn}{2} - 2ne^{-d/3}$, thus we get that
$$ \frac{Z_C^{\mathrm{dis}}}{Z_C} \leq q^{n[1-(1-\eta)(2+1/10)(d/2-2e^{-d/3})/d]} \leq q^{-n[1/20-2\eta+5e^{-d/3}/d]} $$
By the choice of $\eta$, for all $d$ large enough this is at most $q^{-n/40}$. Hence for all $q$ large enough, it is at most $e^{-n}$.

Proof. The main part of the proof is to show that for any configuration $F \in B$ it holds that
$$ c(F) - \frac{2}{d}|E_c \setminus F| \le -\rho n \quad \text{with } \rho = \eta/20. \quad (10) $$
Let us conclude the proof of the lemma assuming (10) for the moment. We first show that (10) translates into $w_c(F)/Z_c \le q^{-\rho n}$ for all $\beta > 0$. Indeed, if $e^\beta - 1 \le q^{2/d}$, we will use the lower bound $Z_c \ge q^{n_c} \ge q^{n(1-e^{-d/3})}$, where the second inequality holds whp. Thus, for any $F \in B$,
$$ \frac{w_c(F)}{Z_c} = \frac{q^{c(F)}(e^\beta-1)^{|F|}}{Z_c} \le q^{c(F)-n+ne^{-d/3}}(e^\beta-1)^{|E_c|-|E_c \setminus F|} \le q^{c(F) - \frac{2}{d}|E_c \setminus F| - n + \frac{2}{d}|E_c| + ne^{-d/3}}. $$
Using that whp $|E_c| \le |E_G| \le nd/2 + \frac{\eta n}{10}$, we have that $\frac{2}{d}|E_c| - n \le n - n + \frac{\eta n}{10}$. Hence, for all d sufficiently large (recall that $\eta$ is an absolute constant independent of d), we obtain that $w_c(F)/Z_c \le q^{-\rho n/4}$. Analogously, if $e^\beta - 1 \ge q^{2/d}$, we use the lower bound $Z_c \ge (e^\beta-1)^{|E_c|}$ so that for any $F \in B$
$$ \frac{w_c(F)}{Z_c} = q^{c(F)}(e^\beta-1)^{-|E_c \setminus F|} \le q^{c(F) - \frac{2}{d}|E_c \setminus F|} \le q^{-\rho n}. $$
To finish, note that the size of $B$ is trivially at most $|\Omega_c| \le 2^{|E_c|} \le 2^{nd/2+n\eta/40}$. Thus we get
$$ \frac{1}{Z_c} \sum_{F \in B} w_c(F) \le 2^{nd/2+n\eta/40} q^{-\rho n/4} $$
which is $\le e^{-n}$ for all q large enough.

We next return to the proof of (10). Fix an arbitrary $F \in B$. We partition the vertices of C into sets $S_1, S_2, S_3, S_4$ depending on the size of their components in $(V_c, F)$. Namely, we set $S_1$ to be the set of vertices in singleton components, $S_2$ the set of vertices in components of size between 2 and $\log n$, $S_3$ the set of vertices in components of size $> \log n$ and $\le n/6$, and $S_4$ the set of vertices in components of size $> n/6$. For $i=1, \dots, 4$, let $n_i := |S_i|$. We have then the trivial upper bound
$$ c(F) \le n_1 + \frac{n_2}{2} + \frac{n_3}{\log n} + 6. \quad (11) $$
Next we give a lower bound on $|E_c\setminus F|$ by analysing how many out-edges are incident to vertices in $S_1, S_2, S_3, S_4$.
1. Consider first components of size 1. Every edge adjacent to any $v \in S_1$ must be in $E_c \setminus F$. Thus, aggregating over $v \in S_1$, we have at least $\frac{1}{2}\text{degg}(S_1)$ edges in $E_c \setminus F$ adjacent to vertices in $S_1$; note that the $\frac{1}{2}$-factor accounts for potential double-counting (edges that join two vertices in $S_1$).
2. Let $k$ be a constant such that whp all sets of size $\le \log n$ are k-treelike (Lemma 29). Also by Lemma 30 whp any connected set of size $\le 2k$ is 1-treelike.
Consider now any component $\kappa$ whose size is between 2 and $\log n$. If $\kappa$ has size $< 2k$, then it is 1-treelike, so $e_G(\kappa) \le |V_G(\kappa)|$. This gives
$$ |E_G(V_G(\kappa), \overline{V_G(\kappa)})| \ge \text{degg}(\kappa) - 2|V_G(\kappa)|. $$
If $\kappa$ has size between $2k$ and $\log n$, the it is k-treelike, so $e_G(\kappa) \le k + |V_G(\kappa)| \le \frac{3}{2}|V_G(\kappa)|$, yielding that
$$ |E_G(V_G(\kappa), \overline{V_G(\kappa)})| \ge \text{degg}(\kappa) - 3|V_G(\kappa)|. $$
Aggregating over all components $\kappa$ in $S_2$, we therefore obtain at least $\frac{1}{2}(\text{degg}(S_2) - 3n_2)$ edges in $E_c\setminus F$ that are adjacent to vertices in $S_2$. (Once again, the factor $\frac{1}{2}$ accounts for double-counting).
3. Consider next components with size between $\log n$ and $\frac{n}{6}$. By Proposition 11 and taking $d$ large enough (namely, $d > A$ where $A$ is the absolute constant there in), we have that whp every connected subset $S$ in $G$ with size $\log n \le |S| \le \frac{n}{6}$ satisfies $|E_G(S,\bar{S})| \ge \frac{3}{5}\text{degg}(S)$. Therefore, for any component $\kappa$ of $(V_c, F)$ in this size range, we have at least $\frac{3}{5}|\text{degg}(\kappa)|$ edges going out of it, and therefore belong to $E_c\setminus F$. Aggregating over $\kappa$ (and accounting once again for potential double-counting), we obtain that the total number of out-edges adjacent to vertices in $S_3$ is at least $\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{3}{5}\text{degg}(S_3)$.
4. Finally consider components with size $> \frac{n}{6}$. If $\eta n/4 \le |S_4| \le n(1-\eta/4)$, we get from the second part of Lemma 33 that for all $d$ large enough $|E_G(S_4, \bar{S_4})| \ge \frac{4d|S_4|(n-|S_4|)}{5n} > \frac{dn\eta}{6}$ (since $\eta/4 \le \frac{|S_4|}{n} \le \frac{3}{4}$). Therefore, the total number of out-edges adjacent to vertices in $S_4$ is at least $\frac{dn\eta}{6}\mathbf{1}\{\eta n/4 \le |S_4| \le (n-\eta n/4)\}$. (Note that if $|S_4|$ is outside the range $\eta n/4$ and $n(1-\eta/4)$ we use the trivial lower bound 0.)

Combining the above, we conclude that
$$ |E_c\setminus F| \ge \frac{1}{2}[\text{degg}(S_1 \cup S_2) - 3n_2 + \frac{3}{5}\text{degg}(S_3) + \frac{dn\eta}{6}\mathbf{1}\{\eta n/4 \le |S_4| \le (1-\eta n/4)\}] $$
$$ \ge \frac{1}{2}[(1-d^{-1/3})d(n_1+n_2+\frac{3}{5}n_3) - 2ne^{-d^{1/3}} + \frac{dn\eta}{6}\mathbf{1}\{\eta n/4 \le |S_4| \le (1-\eta n/4)\}], \quad (12) $$
where the second inequality follows from the fact that the number of vertices of G which have degree $< (1-d^{-1/3})d$ is less than $2ne^{-d^{1/3}}$ (Proposition 41). From (11) and (12), we therefore have that
$$ c(F) - \frac{2}{d}|E_c \setminus F| \le n_1 + (\frac{1}{2}+\frac{3}{d})n_2 + \frac{n_3}{\log n} + 6 - (1-d^{-1/3})[n_1+n_2+\frac{3}{5}n_3] $$
$$ + 2ne^{-d^{1/3}} - \frac{\eta n}{6}\mathbf{1}\{\eta n/4 \le |S_4| \le (n-\eta n/4)\}. $$
For $d$ and $n$ sufficiently large, we have that $\frac{1}{2} - \frac{3}{d} - d^{-1/3} \ge \frac{1}{4}$ and $\frac{1}{\log n} - \frac{3d^{-1/3}}{5} \ge \frac{1}{4}$, so
$$ c(F) - \frac{2}{d}|E_c \setminus F| \le d^{-1/3}n_1 - \frac{n_2+n_3}{4} - \frac{\eta n}{6}\mathbf{1}\{\eta n/4 \le |S_4| \le (n-\eta n/4)\} + 2ne^{-d^{1/3}} + 6. \quad (13) $$
Now we split the analysis into four cases. We will use that whp $|E_c| \ge |E_K| \ge \frac{dn}{2} - 2ne^{-d/3} > \frac{25}{27}\frac{dn}{2}$ for all d large enough (Lemma 39) and also that whp $|E_c| \le |E_G| \le \frac{dn}{2} + \frac{\eta n}{40}$.
- Case 0: $n_3/n \ge 1 - \frac{2\eta}{3}$. Here we show that $|F| < \frac{\eta}{10}|E_c|$, contradicting our assumption on $|F|$ coming from $F \in B$ (and hence we can rule out this case). Indeed, no edge incident to a vertex in $S_1$ is in $F$, so $|E_c \setminus F| \ge \frac{1}{2}\text{degg}(S_1) \ge \frac{1}{2}d(1-d^{-1/3})(n_1 - 2ne^{-d^{1/3}})$ where the last inequality follows from the fact that G has at most $2ne^{-d^{1/3}}$ vertices with degree $< (1-d^{-1/3})d$ (Proposition 41). Hence
$$ |F| = |E_c| - |E_c \setminus F| \le \frac{dn}{2} + \frac{\eta n}{40} - \frac{d}{2}(1-d^{-1/3})(n_1 - 2ne^{-d^{1/3}}). $$
For all d large enough, $\frac{\eta}{40} + \frac{2\eta}{3} + d^{-1/3} + 2e^{-d^{1/3}} \le \frac{5\eta}{6}$, thus also $|F| \le \frac{dn}{2} \cdot \frac{5\eta}{6}$. But $|E_c| > \frac{25}{27}\frac{dn}{2}$, which gives $|F| < \frac{\eta}{10}|E_c|$, contradicting $F \in B$.
- Case 1: $n_4 > n(1-\eta/2)$. Since we have at most 6 components with size $> n/6$, in this case it follows that $c(F) < n - n(1-\eta/2)+6 = \eta n/2 + 6$. Since $|F| \le (1-\frac{\eta}{10})|E_c|$ we have $|E_c \setminus F| \ge \frac{\eta}{10}|E_c| > \frac{\eta}{10}\frac{dn}{3}$, so for n large enough
$$ c(F) - \frac{2}{d}|E_c \setminus F| < 6 + \frac{\eta n}{2} - \frac{2}{d}\frac{\eta}{10}\frac{dn}{3} = 6 - \frac{\eta n}{12} \le -\frac{\eta n}{20}. $$
- Case 2: $n_2+n_3 \ge \eta n/3$. Plugging this into (13) (using the trivial bound $n_1 < n$ and ignoring the indicator), we obtain that
$$ c(F) - \frac{2}{d}|E_c \setminus F| \le d^{-1/3}n - \frac{\eta n}{12} + 2e^{-d^{1/3}} + 6 $$
Since $\eta$ does not depend on $d$, for all $d$ (and $n$) large enough, $d^{-1/3} + 2e^{-d^{1/3}} + 6/n \le \eta/30$, and so for all $n$ large enough, yielding once again (10).
- Case 3: $n_2+n_3 < \eta n/3$, $n_1 < n(1-2\eta/3)$, and $n_4 < n(1-\eta/2)$. Since $n_1+n_2+n_3+n_4 = |V_c|$, we have that $n_4 \ge n_c - n_1 - n_2 - n_3 > n - ne^{-d/3} - n + \frac{2\eta n}{3} - \frac{\eta n}{3} = \frac{\eta n}{3} - ne^{-d/3}$ which is at least $\eta n/4$ for all d large enough. In this case, (13) gives for d and n large that
$$ c(F) - \frac{2}{d}|E_c \setminus F| \le d^{-1/3}n - \frac{\eta n}{6} + 2e^{-d^{1/3}} + 6 \le -\eta n/20. $$
This finishes the proof of (10) and completes the proof of Lemma 53.

Proof. Consider arbitrary $F \in B_1$. As we saw in Case 0 of the proof of Lemma 53, the number of singleton components in $(V_C, F)$ is at most $(1 - \frac{2\eta}{3})n$. Let $S$ be the set of vertices that are in components of size $\ge 2$.
Note that the edges of $F$ have all endpoints in $S$, thus $|F| \le e_G(S)$. Combining Lemmas 29, 30 (with $R$ being the $k$ from the previous lemma) and 35, we get for all $d$ large enough, whp, for any connected subset $S' \subseteq S$ of $(V_C, F)$, $e_G(S') \le |S'|(1+\max(1, d\eta/3))$. Hence, $e_G(S) \le |S|(2+d\eta/3)$. Since $e_G(S) \ge |F| \ge \frac{9\eta}{10}|E_C|$, we must have $|S| \ge \frac{9\eta|E_C|}{10d(\eta/3+2/d)}$. Since each component containing $|S|$ has at least 2 vertices, $c(F) \le n - |S| + |S|/2 = n - |S|/2$. Therefore we can bound
$$ \frac{w_G(F)}{w_G(\emptyset)} = q^{c(F)-n_c}(e^\beta-1)^{|F|} \le q^{n-\frac{9\eta|E_C|}{20d(\eta/3+2/d)}-n_c} (e^\beta-1)^{\frac{9}{10}\eta|E_C|} \le q^{-\frac{9\eta|E_C|}{10d}(\frac{1}{2(\eta/3+2/d)}-21)}, $$
where the last inequality follows from $\beta \le \beta_1$ and that whp $n_c \ge n(1-e^{-d/3})$. For all $d$ large enough $\frac{1}{2(\eta/3+2/d)} - 21 > 1$. By Lemma 39, whp $|E_C| \ge \frac{dn}{2} - 2ne^{-d/3} \ge \frac{dn}{3}$, giving that $\frac{w_G(F)}{Z_C^{\mathrm{dis}}} \le q^{-n[\eta/20-e^{-d/3}]}$. For all $d$ large enough, this is at most $q^{-n\eta/30}$. Aggregating over at most $2^{|E_C|} \le 2^{dn}$ configurations $F$, we get that $\pi_C^{\mathrm{dis}}(B_1) \le e^{-n}$ for all $q$ large enough.
